div.head: The Path way to Peace and Truth, with Holineſſe: Directed to all thoſe who love the Lord JESUS CHRIST in truth and ſincerity.

div.q: John 13. 17. If yee know theſe things, happy are yee if ye doe them.
GAL. 6. 16. And as many as walk according to this Rule, peace be on them, and mercy, and upon the Iſrael of God.

div.head: To the Friendly Reader.
div.p: FRiend, and Reader, if it be thy lot to view this ſmall Piece, it may be thou mayſt make good uſe of it, and give God thanks; but if thou ſcoffingly ſtile me Independent, Separatiſt, or Anabaptiſt, thou art too raſh, and wilt meet with a modeſt reproofe in the ninth of theſe Precepts. They all tend to holineſſe of life, which is the firſt ſtep to peace: For when a mans wayes plea • e the Lord, his enemies ſhall be at peace with him, ſaith the Word. But, There is no peace to the wicked, ſaith the Lord.

div.q: PSAL. 119. 165. Great peace have they which love thy Law, and nothing ſhall hurt them.
PSAL. 119. 5. O that my wayes were directed to keep thy Statutes.

div.head: (I.)
div.p: THE firſt thing that thou art to look unto in this buſineſſe, is, to receive Chriſt into thy heart when he knocketh at the doore thereof (as he doth many wayes, but principally by his Word and Spirit.) For untill then all the ſervice thou offereſt him is abominable. Thou mayſt take an example from thy ſelfe: For when a Friend whom thou dearly loveſt, knocketh at thy doore, thou firſt openeſt unto him, and receiveſt him into thy houſe, cauſeſt him to ſit down, and then adminiſtreſt unto him: But if thou offer him any thing at the doore, it is a ſigne he is a Beggar, and one whom thou rather hireſt by thy gifts to depart from thee, then inviteſt to abide with thee. And when Chriſt hath once poſſeſſion in thy heart, he will purge it of all corruption and uncleanneſſe; This is that which David ſo much deſired, Pſam 51. 10. Create in me a clean heart, O God: And then all other Chriſtian duties will follow, as the threed followeth the needle, and Chriſt ſhall ſweetly ſubject every part and faculty both of ſoul and body, to a willing obedience of the Goſpel. And as thou entertaineſt him into thy houſe of clay; ſo will he entertain thee into his Fathers Houſe, wherein are many glorious Manſions, and there thou ſhalt remain with him and the reſt of his bleſſed Saints and Angels in eternall joy for ever and ever.

div.head: (II.)
div.p: The next thing thou art to endevour, is, to become (if thou be not already) a member of the true Church of Chriſt, of his ſpirituall Kingdome, which he hath choſen and purchaſed to himſelfe with the price of his moſt pretious blood, as his peculiar inheritance, unto whom, and with whom he hath made his covenant & promiſe of love, preſence, protection, preſervation and bleſſing; and upon whom he wil multiply the graces of his holy Spirit abundantly. This is his Vineyard, which his own right hand hath planted in a fruitful land, with the choiſeſt vine, and fenced it about for ſafety, (Iſa. 5.) from the wild Boares of the Forreſt, and from the little Foxes which deſtroy, Cant. 2. 15. This is his Walled Sheep fold, in which are incloſed his tender lambs, which he leadeth into pleaſant paſtures, and conducteth in the paths of righteouſneſſe, and cauſeth them to lie down in ſafety, Pſal. 23. himſelfe being the good Shepheard, John 10. 11. This is his watered Garden wherein he taketh delight, Cant. 4. 12. This is the Citie of the great God, wherein he is worſhipped, and his Name called upon, whereof thou art a Citizen. This is Gods Houſe, of whoſe Family thou art: which Houſe and City are built upon a ſure foundation: Of this ſpirituall Kingdom Chriſt is the only King, Governour, and law-giver: Take heed therefore that thou ſubmit not thy ſelfe unto any conſcience-binding law of Antichriſt his enemy; beare not his mark neither on thy fore-head, nor in thy hand; if thou do, thou loſeſt all the former priviledges: for Chriſt will admit no partner with him in his govrnment; the Ark of God and Dagon cannot ſtand together, nor Chriſt and Belial. No Kingdome ſo ſafe as this, becauſe the Keeper thereof neither ſlumbreth nor ſleepeth; and all the Officers are watch-men, watching over all the ſubjects ingenerall; and every ſubject alſo watching over each other in particular.

div.head: (III.)
div.p: When God hath thus honoured thee, as to make thee a ſubject of his Kingdome, ſee that thou yeeld obedience unto all his Lawes, and ſubject thy ſelfe wholly thereunto, and utterly renounce obedience unto the Lawes of any King, or Kingdome, that hold not correſpondency with this; and let the grace of God which thou haſt received teach thee to deny all ungodlineſſe, and worldly luſts; and to live righteouſly, and ſoberly in this preſent world, that thou diſhonour not the profeſſion which thou haſt taken upon thee by thy ill converſation: but let thy light ſo ſhine before men, that they ſeeing thy good workes may glorifie thy father which is in heaven, and ſay of a truth, God is in thee indeed, and ſo be induced to walke with thee in the wayes of piety, and godlyneſſe. For the reproach of a ſcandall in thee, reflecteth not ſo much upon thy ſelfe, as upon thy profeſſion; for the uncircumciſed in heart wil frequently ſay, This is the religion of ſuch a Church, ſuch a people, and ſo the Goſpel of Chriſt is evill ſpoken off through thy bad converſation; and a multitude of pretious Saints may undergoe rebuke as the Church of Corinth did (1 Cor. 5.) for one mans offence, or elſe puniſhment, as many thouſands did, for one Achan; O that men would therefore feare the Lord, and depart from iniquity, that it might go well with their ſoules.

div.head: (IV.)
div.p: Neither muſt thou reſt thy ſelfe contented with theſe former graces, (viz.) that thou art Gods ſervant, and liveſt uprightly and juſtly, doing no man wrong; but thou muſt apply thy ſelfe to doing good: For many bruit beaſts wil live amongſt us all their lives, and never hurt either us, or any of their own Species, or Kind; but thou who haſt obtained faith, and other graces from God, muſt be active in doing good: For the Apoſtle (James 1. 27) teacheth a religious man to viſit the Fatherleſſe and widow, as wel as to keep himſelf unſpotted of the world. And David counſels us as well to doe good, as eſchew evill, Pſal. 14. If thou be a Vine in Gods Vineyard, he expects grapes from thee: If thou be a Tree in his Orchard, he expects fruit: for thou mayſt bear leaves abundantly, and yet be accurſed. Imitate therefore bleſſed Job, be an eye to the blind, a foot to the Lame, let the naked be cloathed with the fleeces of thy flocks, diſtribute thy bread unto the hungry, thy drink unto the thirſty, viſit thoſe that are ſick and in priſon, and turn not thy face from the poore, and remember that Divine ſaying of the Apoſtle, 1 John 3. 17. Whoſoever hath this worlds goods, and ſeeth his brotther in want, and ſhutteth up the bowels of his compaſſion againſt him, the love of God is not in him. For if thou hadſt all other vertues and graces, and want Charity, thou art nothing.

div.head: (V.)
div.p: And if thou canſt not live ſo holily as thou deſireſt, and as the word of God requires, yet thou muſt ardently endeavour it. For the holy deſires of the Saints have alwayes been accepted of God as the deed; if in the mean time thou labour to crucifie the world, and through the Spirit to mortify the deeds of the fleſh. If therefore thou canſt not bring great offerings of devotion unto God, as prayer, thankſgiving, alms, and the like, come unto him with that which thou haſt, and offer it with good will and holy deſires: For ſo much as thou deſireſt to offer unto God, ſo great doth he eſteem thy Sacrifice in his ſight; for he hath given thee no more, and more then he hath given thee, he will not require at thy hand: And Chriſt ſhall fulfill thy lame and imperfect prayers and ſacrifices with his moſt abſolute & perfect ſacrifice. And then it cannot be but God ſhall accept thine at thy hands, as acceptably as he did his Sons: For herein he doth, as it were, exchange Chriſts merirs with thee for thy pious deſires; and for thy imperfect ſacrifie, ſhall (out of the abundance of his mercy, and not for, any merit of thine) give thee an eternall weight of glory hereafter.

div.head: (VI.)
div.p: When thou findeſt theſe former graces beſtowed upon thee by the Lord, take heede thou be not puffed up with ſpirituall pride, to ſay in thy heart as the Phariſee did, Lord, I am not as other men; for unto this Satan will continually provoke thee, labouring to deſtroy the image of God in thee, and to ſet up his own; and ſo infecting thee with that ſin for which he was caſt out of heaven, to bring thee into the ſame condition with him, and ſo deprive thee of all ſpirituall comfort for ever. But remember thou the words of the Apoſtle, What haſt thou that thou haſt not received? And if thou haſt received it, why boaſteſt thou as if thou hadſt not received it? for God is the giver of every good and perfect gift, the good thoughts of thy heart come onely from him, he like a rich Jeweller putteth his treaſures into what trunke or cheſt he pleaſeth, and at his pleaſure removeth them againe. Serve thou the Lord with fear, and endeavour to improve thoſe gifts and graces which he hath given unto thee, leſt he take them from thee, and beſtow them upon others, who will bring forth the fruits of them.

div.head: (VII.)
div.p: Whatſoever thou doeſt in Gods worſhip and ſervice, or in thy duty to thy neighbour, let it be done in uprightneſſe, and ſincerity of heart, without diſmulation, or hypocriſie, and be not ſo ſtupid as to thinke the Lord ſees not, or knowes not; for he that made the heart knoweth the inwards thereof, and will judge thee according to the ſame; and he hath given thee a conſcience, who within thee executeth the office of a Clarke, writing up every word thou ſpeakeſt, every deed thou doeſt, and every thought thou thinkeſt (ſo that it is a folly to diſſemble) he writeth nothing more then he ſhould, neither omitteth any thing. And as he writeth it for thee, ſo doth he continually read it unto thee, that thou can'ſt neither forget, or deny any the leaſt part of it, and at the barr of Gods judgement at the laſt day, thou ſhalt have no other judge to acquit or condemn thee. There ſhall be no defending or proving, nor need of any other witneſſe. Remember then the Councel of holy David to his ſon Solomon, who commands him in the firſt part of Gods worſhip, to ſerve him with an upright heart, adding the reaſon: for the Lord, ſaith he, ſearcheth all hearts, and underſtandeth the ſecret imaginations of the thoughts; 1 Chron. 28. 9. ſo that of all fooles in the world, he that thinkes to deceive the Lord, is the greateſt.

div.head: (VIII.)
div.p: Be not over-curious in prying into the faults of others, nor too raſh in cenſuring them: for though they have not proceeded ſo far as thy ſelf in the performance of externall duties, yet they may ſuddenly be converted, and exceed thee. And though they live in groſſe ſins, condemne them not, but pitty them and pray for them, and be thankfull to God who hath called thee to ſome obedience, who might have left thee in a worſe eſtate then they are in, if his grace had not prevented thee. It is oftentimes ſeen, no greater hypocrites, nor unſound and hollow-hearted people, then theſe find-faults, whom our Saviour calls hypocrites, commanding them to caſt the beam out of their owne eye firſt, that they may the clearer ſee the moat in anothers. For while thy mind is wandring abroad to find fault with others, Satan in the mean time builds a neſt at home in thy heart, where he hatcheth theſe unclean birds of pride, hypocriſie, ſelf-love, diſdain of others, &c. which devour the bleſſed fruits of the Spirit, as humility, meekneſſe, lowlineſſe, brotherly love & kindneſſe; much hindering the growth of grace in thee, and diminiſhing ſpiritual comfort, and will lie heavie upon thy conſcience, when God ſhall diſcover it unto thee. As therefore thou lookeſt unto others with one eye, look into thy ſelfe with the other, leſt thou fall under the reproof of our Saviour fore-mentioned, Luk. 6. 41. 42.

div.head: (IX.)
div.p: If thou wouldſt enjoy the bleſſings of God either ſpirituall or temporall with comfort, labour for peace both in thy ſelf and with others. For peace is unto all Gods bleſſings as ſalt is to meat, which ſeaſoneth it in ſuch manner, that it continueth long both profitable and comfortable, without which it would ſoon become unſavoury and uſeleſſe. Wherefore the Apoſtles frequently in their Epiſtles wiſhing all good to the Churches of Chriſt, mention only grace and peace, including all other bleſſings therein, (as 1 Pet. 1. 2. Phil. 1. 2. Gal. 1. 3.) yea, and ſomtimes no more but the word peace alone, as 1 Pet. 5. 14. The want of this bleſsing hath brought this Kingdom almoſt unto utter ruine, and thouſands of perſons and families altogether to deſtruction both of their bodies and eſtates. If therefore thou wouldſt enjoy this bleſſing, thou muſt firſt make account to undergoe much wrong at • he hands of men, which although it be diſpleaſing to thy nature, yet it is well-pleaſing to God, and agreeable to the exhortation of Chriſt, and will bring much comfort to thy ſoul. Secondly, give not liberty to thy tongue to revile when thou art reviled, nor ſcoffe when thou art ſcoffed; for theſe two vices are commonly the fomenting inſtruments of all miſchief amongſt friends and neighbours, as the Apoſtle ſpeaks, Jam. 3. 6. And when thou ſeeſt two ſtriving to vanquiſh each other in either of theſe, thou mayſt boldly conclude, they contend who ſhall run ſwifteſt to Hell. Remember then that divine heavenly caveat of the Apoſtle, Jam. 1. 26. If any man among you ſeem to bee religious, and bridleth not his tongue, but deceiveth his own heart, this mans religion is in vain. And, Jam. 3. 2. If any man offend not in word, he is a perfect man, and able to rule the whole body.

div.head: (X.)
div.p: The laſt exhortation which I give unto thee at this time, is, that thou (through covetouſnes) uſe no fraud, deceit, or guile in thy calling. This is a ſin as dangerous as common; and becauſe it brings with it ſome worldly profit, men are content to live in it, though to the hazard of their moſt pretious ſouls; yea, even many whom God hath honored with rare and excellent gifts of zeal and devotion; as, conſtant in hearing and reading the word, in prayer and family duties, and full of heavenly exhortations: yet are as deeply guilty of this ſin, as thoſe who are openly prophane, and never think of anſwering at the laſt day. And this is lamentable to conſider. I wiſh all men therefore to remember what Solomon ſaith, Pro. 13. verſ. 11. Wealth gotten by vanity ſhall be diminiſhed. And, Jer. 17. 11. He that gathereth riches, and not by right, ſhall leave them in the midst of his dayes, and at his end ſhall be a fool. And, what ſhall it profit thee to win the whole world, and loſe thy own ſoul? I would demād of thee, if thou be cōſcientious, what thou wilt do with mony falſly gotten? Wilt thou pray to God to bleſſe it unto thee? Then thou makeſt him (what in thee lies) partner with thee in thy cheating & thievery, according to Pſal. 50. 18. Wilt thou buy meat or drink with it? Thou mayſt fear it will either choke or poyſon thee. Wilt thou buy raiment therwith? Thou mayſt tremble in putting them on, fearing leſt they ſhould infect thee with ſome loathſome diſeaſe. Wilt thou buy houſe or land therewith? It will never continue to the third generation. Wilt thou give it the poor? It is no way acceptable to God, becauſe it is not thine own. Wilt thou put it among other mony lawfully gotten? It will be but as a coal of fire in a peece of wax, to melt and conſume it. Wilt thou caſt it into the Treaſury of the Church? It is but as the hire of a Whore, or the price of a Dog, forbidden by Moſes Law, Deut. 23. 18. Wilt thou caſt it away? That were a ſin. What wilt thou then doe with it? Surely Zacheus reſolution is the only way, viz. (Luk • . 19. 8.) to reſtore it fourfold. But if thou knoweſt not how, or to whom to reſtore it, then (in my judgement) it properly belongs to the poore. But, alas! thoſe who are once infected with this diſeaſe of Covetouſneſſe, may fitly be compared to cloath, which once died black, is ever after uncapable of any other colour: ſo thoſe whom Satan hath once lul'd aſleep in this ſin, ſeldom or never awake but with the ſcorching flames of hell fire about their ears. From which the Lord deliver us all. Amen.

q.p: Let us heare the concluſion of the whole matter, Feare God, and keep his Commandements; for this is the whole duty of man.
For God ſhall bring every work into judgement, with every ſecret thing, whether it bee good or evill.
